content:
The Water Quality Protection and Job Creation Act of 2017 includes amendments to the Federal Water Pollution Control Act. It also covers water quality financing, technical assistance, state management assistance, watershed pilot projects, and nonpoint source management programs. Additionally, it addresses State Water Pollution Control Revolving Funds. TITLE II--ALTERNATIVE WATER SOURCE AND SEWER OVERFLOW AND STORMWATER GRANTS

Sec. 201. Pilot program for alternative water source projects.
Sec. 202. Sewer overflow control grants.

SEC. 2. AMENDMENT OF FEDERAL WATER POLLUTION CONTROL ACT. Section 104(b) of the Federal Water Pollution Control Act is amended to include making grants to nonprofit organizations for providing technical assistance to rural, small, and tribal municipalities in planning, developing, and financing eligible projects. The amendment aims to provide grants for technical assistance to rural, small, and tribal municipalities for wastewater treatment systems to protect water quality and ensure compliance with regulations. Authorization of appropriations is also amended accordingly. The amendment increases funding to $100,000,000 annually for fiscal years 2018 through 2022 for specific subsections related to wastewater treatment systems in rural, small, and tribal municipalities. SEC. 102. STATE MANAGEMENT ASSISTANCE. Authorization of Appropriations for fiscal years 1991 through 2017 and $300,000,000 for each of fiscal years 2018 through 2022. Technical Amendment to Section 106(e).

SEC. 103. WATERSHED PILOT PROJECTS. Authorization of Appropriations of $120,000,000 for each of fiscal years 2018 through 2022 for watershed pilot projects. SEC. 104. NONPOINT SOURCE MANAGEMENT PROGRAMS. Amends Section 319(j) to increase funding to $200,000,000 for each fiscal year from 2018 through 2022. SEC. 121 amends Section 602(b) to require states to use at least 15 percent of capitalization grants for assisting small municipalities. SEC. 122 addresses water pollution control revolving loan funds. Section 603(d) (33 U.S.C. 1383(d)) is amended to provide grants to owners and operators of treatment works serving populations of 10,000 or fewer for technical and planning assistance, financial management, user fee analysis, budgeting, and facility operation and maintenance. The total amount of grants provided by the State under this paragraph for a fiscal year cannot exceed one percent of the total assistance provided by the State. The State provides grants to owners and operators of treatment works for assessing energy and water consumption, identifying conservation opportunities, and promoting efficient use of resources. The total grant amount for a fiscal year cannot exceed one percent of the total assistance provided by the State. The State provides grants for assessing energy and water consumption in treatment works. The grant amount cannot exceed 1% of the total assistance provided by the State in the preceding fiscal year or 2% of the total received in capitalization grants, whichever is greater. SEC. 123. State planning assistance amended from 1 percent to 2 percent. SEC. 124. Intended use plan. For fiscal year 2019 and beyond, states must prioritize projects seeking assistance from their water pollution control revolving fund based on a specified methodology. Financial aid can only be provided for projects listed on this priority list, which may include nonpoint sources of pollution. Each State must establish a methodology for developing a priority list for water quality improvement projects, considering various factors, including the requirements of section 602(b)(5). The State must establish a methodology for selecting water quality improvement projects based on factors such as addressing impairments associated with treatment works and considering information from state planning processes. The State must consider various factors when selecting water quality improvement projects, including their potential beneficial impact, the State's management program, and conservation plans for estuaries within the State. Nonpoint sources of pollution on the priority list should also be evaluated for cumulative water quality improvements from related projects. The State may use existing methodologies for activities related to listed categories or subcategories. Section 606(c) is amended to include the State's priority list in the Intended Use Plan. Before completion of a priority list based on a methodology established under section 603(g) of the Federal Water Pollution Control Act, a State must explain any changes in project funding order. SEC. 125. TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE. The Administrator will help States establish simplified procedures for treatment works to receive assistance under this title. A manual will be published to aid treatment works in obtaining assistance. SEC. 126. AUTHORIZATION OF APPROPRIATIONS. Authorization of appropriations for Title VI is added. "Authorization of $4 billion for fiscal years 2018-2022 for Title II grants, including a pilot program for alternative water source projects." SEC. 201 amends selection process, committee resolution procedure, definitions, and authorization of appropriations for alternative water source projects. SEC. 202 focuses on sewer overflow control grants. Section 221 (33 U.S.C. 1301) is amended to provide grants for planning, design, and construction of treatment works for sewer overflow and stormwater reuse projects. Grants can be given to states for distribution to municipalities or directly to municipalities for these purposes. The section is amended to provide grants for sewer overflow and stormwater reuse projects. It authorizes $500,000,000 for each fiscal year from 2018 to 2022 for project assistance, subject to state requirements. The Administrator shall allocate $500,000,000 annually from 2018 to 2022 for sewer overflow and stormwater reuse projects. States must use at least 20% of the grants for green infrastructure and environmentally innovative activities. The Administrator will allocate funds annually from 2018 to 2022 for sewer overflow and stormwater reuse projects. Grants will be distributed to municipalities and municipal entities in 2018 and to States in 2019 and beyond based on established criteria and a formula determined by the Administrator. The Administrator will allocate funds annually from 2018 to 2022 for sewer overflow and stormwater reuse projects, based on established criteria and a formula determined by the Administrator. Sanitary sewer overflow controls and stormwater information will be considered as well.
